questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sign indicating adequate growth in an infant with a birth weight of 3 kg? (NEET PG 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Increase in length of 25 cm in the first year

options.label: B
options.text: Weight gain of 300 grams per month till 1 year

options.label: C
options.text: Anterior fontanelle closure by 6 months of age

options.label: D
options.text: Weight under 75th percentile and height under 25th percentile

questions.correct_answer: A. Increase in length of 25 cm in the first year
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Increase in length of 25 cm in the first year

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An increase in length of 25 cm in the first year is a key indicator of adequate growth in infants.

questions.text: What is the SI unit used to measure the brightness of light from a point source among the options provided?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Candela

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of N-acetylcysteine in paracetamol toxicity? (FMGE JAN 2025)

options.label: B
options.text: It inhibits the cytochrome P450 enzyme responsible for NAPQI formation

options.label: C
options.text: It acts as a direct antioxidant to neutralize NAPQI

options.label: D
options.text: It enhances renal clearance of NAPQI

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) It replenishes glutathione levels

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • N-acetylcysteine works by replenishing glutathione levels in paracetamol toxicity. Paracetamol is metabolized by cytochrome P450 enzymes to form NAPQI (N-acetyl-para-benzoquinoneimine), which is a toxic metabolite.
  • • Normally, glutathione in the liver neutralizes NAPQI. However, toxicity occurs in three scenarios:
  • • High doses of paracetamol leading to excessive NAPQI formation Chronic alcoholism causing increased CYP enzyme activity Liver disease reducing glutathione production
  • • High doses of paracetamol leading to excessive NAPQI formation
  • • Chronic alcoholism causing increased CYP enzyme activity
  • • Liver disease reducing glutathione production
  • • N-acetylcysteine is converted to glutathione, which then binds and neutralizes NAPQI. For maximum effectiveness, N-acetylcysteine should be administered within 8 hours of paracetamol ingestion.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. It inhibits the cytochrome P450 enzyme responsible for NAPQI formation: Incorrect - N-acetylcysteine does not inhibit cytochrome P450 enzymes. It works by replenishing glutathione which neutralizes NAPQI after its formation.
  • • Option B. It inhibits the cytochrome P450 enzyme responsible for NAPQI formation: Incorrect -
  • • Option C. It acts as a direct antioxidant to neutralize NAPQI: Incorrect - N-acetylcysteine does not directly neutralize NAPQI. It is first converted to glutathione, which then neutralizes NAPQI.
  • • Option C. It acts as a direct antioxidant to neutralize NAPQI: Incorrect -
  • • Option D. It enhances renal clearance of NAPQI: Incorrect - N-acetylcysteine does not enhance renal clearance of NAPQI. Its mechanism involves glutathione replenishment.
  • • Option D. It enhances renal clearance of NAPQI: Incorrect -

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ N-acetylcysteine is the antidote for paracetamol toxicity and works by replenishing glutathione levels, which helps neutralize the toxic metabolite NAPQI.
  • ➤ Antidotes
  • ➤ Antidotes

questions.text: Oxygen sensitive channels in peripheral chemoreceptors are for which of the following ion? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) K+

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The primary ion involved in oxygen sensing in peripheral chemoreceptors is potassium (K+). The closure of oxygen-sensitive potassium channels during hypoxia is a crucial step in the signaling pathway that regulates respiratory response to low oxygen levels.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents with headache and seizures. On examination his BP is 220/110 mm Hg. What is the most appropriate treatment? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) IV Labetalol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In neurological hypertensive emergencies, the first-line treatment options for reducing blood pressure are IV nicardipine or IV labetalol, with IV labetalol being preferred if IV nicardipine is unavailable.

questions.text: A female patient presents with severe restlessness, palpitations, and tremors to the emergency department. She is a known case of bronchial asthma. On examination, the neck looks swollen. Blood pressure is elevated, and tachycardia is noted. ECG shows atrial fibrillation. Which of the following drugs is used for immediate management in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Diltiazem

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For immediate rate control in atrial fibrillation in a patient with bronchial asthma, non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers like diltiazem are preferred over beta-blockers to avoid exacerbating asthma symptoms.

questions.text: Spread of prostate cancer to lumbar vertebra occurs via? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Venous

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Prostate cancer spreads to lumbar vertebrae through:
  • • Bateson's venous plexus (vertebral venous plexus) This is a valveless system allowing bidirectional flow Connects prostatic venous plexus to vertebral veins Most common cancer in men with bone metastasis Typically produces osteoblastic lesions in bones
  • • Bateson's venous plexus (vertebral venous plexus)
  • • This is a valveless system allowing bidirectional flow
  • • Connects prostatic venous plexus to vertebral veins
  • • Most common cancer in men with bone metastasis
  • • Typically produces osteoblastic lesions in bones
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Direct : Incorrect as prostate is anatomically distant from lumbar vertebrae making direct spread impossible
  • • Option A. Direct
  • • Option B. Arterial : Incorrect as prostatic venous plexus connection to vertebrae via Bateson's plexus is the established pathway
  • • Option B. Arterial
  • • Option D. Lymphatic : Incorrect as lymphatic spread of prostate cancer is typically to pelvic and para-aortic nodes, not directly to vertebrae
  • • Option D. Lymphatic

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prostate cancer spreads to lumbar vertebrae through Bateson's venous plexus, making it the most common cancer in men with bone metastasis.
  • ➤ Spread of CA Prostate
  • ➤ Spread of CA Prostate

questions.text: A person reported to OPD alongside his 32-year-old brother working in a factory. The brother was recently subjected to a test – Coproporphyrin in urine. The physician should suspect: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Coproporphyrin in urine is an important screening test for lead poisoning, indicating exposure to lead, and should be followed by diagnostic tests to assess absorption.

questions.text: Below is an electron microscopy depiction of a cellular structure. Determine the type of cell being depicted. (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hairy cell

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hairy cells are seen in hairy cell leukemia, characterized by B lymphocytes with hair-like projections, and are identified using electron microscopy and specific markers like CD11c, CD25, CD103, and Annexin-A.

questions.text: Which of the following is a true/correct statement about paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria? (NEET PG 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: It is an inherited red blood cell disorder causing intravascular hemolysis

options.label: B
options.text: The diagnosis of the disorder is confirmed by sucrose lysis test

options.label: C
options.text: Flow cytometry is the gold standard for diagnosing this condition

options.label: D
options.text: The commonest cause of mortality is cardiac failure

questions.correct_answer: C. Flow cytometry is the gold standard for diagnosing this condition
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Flow cytometry is the definitive test for diagnosing PNH by demonstrating the absence of CD55 and CD59 on blood cells.

questions.text: Meiosis occurs in:(NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Adult ovary

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Adult ovary are responsible for producing ova (egg cells) and hormones such as estrogen and progesterone. Meiosis begins in the fetal ovaries but is arrested in prophase I until puberty.
  • ➤ Adult ovary
  • ➤ arrested in prophase I
  • ➤ After puberty, with each menstrual cycle, some oocytes resume meiosis, completing meiosis I and arresting in meiosis II. It's only after fertilization that meiosis II completes . Therefore, meiosis occurs in the adult ovary as it is essential for the formation of mature ova or egg cells.
  • ➤ It's only after fertilization that meiosis II completes

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with an ulcerative lesion near the medial canthus of his eye, featuring pearly margins. Microscopic examination reveals a palisading arrangement of cells, along with keratin pearls. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Basal cell carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Basal cell carcinoma presenting as an ulcerative lesion with pearly margins (rodent ulcer) is characteristic, especially in the periocular region, with microscopic findings of peripheral palisading arrangement of basaloid cells.

questions.text: A patient presented with 2 Lisch nodules in the iris. What is the possible diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Neurofibromatosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of Lisch nodules in the iris is highly specific for Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), making it a key diagnostic feature for this condition

questions.text: A fracture that involves the epiphysis, physis, and metaphysis is classified as which type of Salter-Harris fracture? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Salter-Harris Type IV fractures are the only type that involve all three anatomical components (epiphysis, physis, and metaphysis) and therefore have a high risk of growth disturbance, requiring accurate reduction to prevent long-term complications.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female presented with anemia. What is the most common cause? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Iron deficiency anemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Iron deficiency anemia is the most common cause of anemia, especially in elderly patients, and requires thorough evaluation to rule out serious underlying conditions such as gastrointestinal malignancies.

questions.text: What is the most common complication associated with the following abnormality? ( NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Exposure keratopathy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Eyelid colobomas can be an isolated finding or can be associated with various syndromes mentioned below:

questions.text: A 2-year-old child with stable vitals and ECG showing PSVT. What is the appropriate management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Adenosine 0.1 mg/kg

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For stable PSVT in children, adenosine is the first-line treatment, starting at a dose of 0.1 mg/kg. If this dose is ineffective, the dose may be escalated in subsequent attempts.

questions.text: The inferior epigastric artery originates from which of the following arteries? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The inferior epigastric artery is a branch of the external iliac artery that runs upward in the anterior abdominal wall to supply the rectus abdominis muscle and forms an important anastomosis with the superior epigastric artery, creating a connection between the subclavian and external iliac arterial systems.

questions.text: A boy fell while playing and suffered an abrasion injury on his knees. The dark brown scab will be seen in how many days? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 4-7 days

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Abrasions heal in a predictable manner , forming a scab due to drying of blood, serum, and tissue fluids . The color of the scab changes over time , providing a reliable estimate of injury duration:
  • • predictable manner
  • • scab
  • • drying of blood, serum, and tissue fluids
  • • color of the scab changes over time
  • • Timeline of Scab Formation in Abrasions
  • • Timeline of Scab Formation in Abrasions
  • • Day 1 (Fresh wound) → Bright red due to oozing blood & lymph . 12-24 hours → Reddish scab begins to form. 2-3 days → Reddish-brown scab develops. 4-7 days → Dark brown to black scab appears as the wound dries​ >7 days → Scab begins to peel off , leaving a depigmented area that gradually fades.
  • • Day 1 (Fresh wound) → Bright red due to oozing blood & lymph .
  • • Day 1 (Fresh wound)
  • • Bright red
  • • oozing blood & lymph
  • • 12-24 hours → Reddish scab begins to form.
  • • 12-24 hours
  • • Reddish scab
  • • 2-3 days → Reddish-brown scab develops.
  • • 2-3 days
  • • Reddish-brown scab
  • • 4-7 days → Dark brown to black scab appears as the wound dries​
  • • 4-7 days
  • • Dark brown to black scab
  • • >7 days → Scab begins to peel off , leaving a depigmented area that gradually fades.
  • • >7 days
  • • Scab begins to peel off
  • • depigmented area
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Day 1: Incorrect. Fresh abrasion will appear bright red with oozing blood and lymph , not a dark brown scab.
  • • Option A. Day 1:
  • • bright red
  • • oozing blood and lymph
  • • Option B. 2-3 days: Incorrect. Scab forms but is reddish-brown , not dark brown.
  • • Option B. 2-3 days:
  • • reddish-brown
  • • Option D. >7 days: Incorrect. By >7 days , the scab starts falling off , revealing new epithelium underneath.
  • • Option D. >7 days:
  • • >7 days
  • • scab starts falling off
  • • new epithelium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Age of Abrasion
  • ➤ Age of Abrasion

questions.text: A patient is undergoing treatment for cancer with methotrexate. What is the mechanism of action? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Inhibits dihydrofolic acid reductase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Methotrexate is an antimetabolite drug that inhibits dihydrofolic acid reductase, an enzyme crucial for DNA synthesis. This mechanism disrupts cell division, making it effective in treating cancer.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for postpartum blues?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Support and education

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Postpartum blues (or "baby blues") is a mild, transient mood disturbance that affects up to 30-75% of postpartum women. Symptoms include mood lability, tearfulness, sadness, and sleep disturbances. It typically occurs within the first week (3-5 days) after delivery and resolves spontaneously within days to weeks. Mainstay of management is reassurance, support, and education.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 839.

questions.text: A woman with endometrial carcinoma is undergoing radiotherapy. Which of the following is true? (NEET PF 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Intensity is inversely proportional to squared distance

options.label: B
options.text: Small blood vessels are most radioresistant

options.label: C
options.text: Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant

questions.correct_answer: A. Intensity is inversely proportional to squared distance
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Intensity is inversely proportional to squared distance

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • This statement refers to the Inverse Square Law, which states that the intensity of radiation is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source. This means that as the distance from the radiation source increases, the intensity of the radiation decreases exponentially. This law is fundamental in radiation physics and is crucial for understanding radiation exposure and protection.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Small blood vessels are most radioresistant: This is incorrect. Larger vessels are more radioresistant compared to smaller ones. The endothelial cells lining small vessels are more susceptible to radiation damage due to their relatively higher rate of proliferation.
  • • Option B. Small blood vessels are most radioresistant:
  • • Option C. Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant: This is incorrect. Rapidly proliferating cells are the most radiosensitive. Cells that are dividing quickly, such as those in the gastrointestinal tract, bone marrow, and reproductive tissues, are more susceptible to radiation damage because radiation primarily affects DNA during cell division.
  • • Option C. Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant:
  • • Option D. Small bowel is most radioresistant: This is incorrect. The gastrointestinal (GI) tract, including the small bowel, is among the most radiosensitive organ systems in the body. This high radiosensitivity is due to the rapid turnover of the epithelial cells lining the GI tract.
  • • Option D. Small bowel is most radioresistant:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The intensity of radiation is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source, as described by the Inverse Square Law.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 610, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 610, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.text: A patient complains that he often gets troubled at night during sleep by tingling and numbness that involves his lateral three digits. He further explains that symptoms are relieved as he lays his arms hanging from the bed. Correct regarding the condition is: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) CTS: Durkan test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given clinical symptoms of the patient suggest presence of carpal tunnel syndrome. The most specific test to check median nerve compression in the carpal tunnel is the Durkan’s Test.
  • ➤ The given clinical symptoms of the patient suggest presence of carpal tunnel syndrome. The most specific test to check median nerve compression in the carpal tunnel is the Durkan’s Test.

questions.text: A young patient presents with rapidly growing lymph nodes around the jaw. His biopsy confirms the diagnosis of Burkitt's lymphoma. Which gene mutation is most commonly implicated in this condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) C-myc

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Burkitt's lymphoma is characterized by translocation of the C-myc proto-oncogene , most commonly t(8;14), resulting in overexpression of C-myc and rapid cellular proliferation.
  • ➤ C-myc proto-oncogene

questions.text: Vaccine kept at the lowest level inside an Ice lined refrigerator (ILR) at PHC: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ OPV is stored at the lowest level of the ILR due to its requirement for the coldest storage conditions, ranging from 2°C and even tolerating freezing conditions, ensuring vaccine potency and effectiveness.
